Article.ArticleTitle: Brain-computer interfaces for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

Abstract.AbstractText: A brain-computer interface (BCI) is a device that detects signals from the brain and transforms them into useful commands. Researchers have developed BCIs that utilize different kinds of brain signals. These different BCI systems have differing characteristics, such as the amount of training required and the degree to which they are or are not invasive. Much of the research on BCIs to date has involved healthy individuals and evaluation of classification algorithms. Some BCIs have been shown to have potential benefit for users with minimal muscular function as a result of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. However, there are still several challenges that need to be successfully addressed before BCIs can be clinically useful.

AffiliationInfo.Affiliation: National Center for Adaptive Neurotechnologies, Albany, New York.

MedlineCitation.CoiStatement: CONFLICT OF INTEREST. The author declares no conflicts of interest.
